title: Lesson 3
description:
Have you ever wondered how life continues from one generation to the next? Whether it’s a puppy being born, a flower blooming, or a mushroom popping up after the rain—every living thing has its own way of making more of itself. In this lesson, we’ll explore the fascinating world of reproduction, where science meets the miracle of life. You’ll discover how some organisms need two parents to create offspring (that’s sexual reproduction!) while others can do it solo, cloning themselves without a partner (asexual reproduction). It’s like nature’s version of teamwork vs. going solo—and both are pretty amazing!

From fish that release millions of eggs into the water to plants that grow new versions of themselves from stems and roots, reproduction comes in all shapes and styles. You’ll learn how animals and plants pass on their traits, how fertilization works, and why diversity in offspring helps species survive. By the end of this module, you’ll be able to spot the differences between internal and external fertilization, name the types of asexual reproduction, and even explain how a potato can grow into a whole new plant. Ready to dive in? Let’s explore how life keeps going, one generation at a time!

content_data.text:
Introduction

 

Have you ever wondered how life continues from one generation to the next? Whether it’s a puppy being born, a flower blooming, or a mushroom popping up after the rain—every living thing has its own way of making more of itself. In this lesson, we’ll explore the fascinating world of reproduction, where science meets the miracle of life. You’ll discover how some organisms need two parents to create offspring (that’s sexual reproduction!) while others can do it solo, cloning themselves without a partner (asexual reproduction). It’s like nature’s version of teamwork vs. going solo—and both are pretty amazing!

 

From fish that release millions of eggs into the water to plants that grow new versions of themselves from stems and roots, reproduction comes in all shapes and styles. You’ll learn how animals and plants pass on their traits, how fertilization works, and why diversity in offspring helps species survive. By the end of this module, you’ll be able to spot the differences between internal and external fertilization, name the types of asexual reproduction, and even explain how a potato can grow into a whole new plant. Ready to dive in? Let’s explore how life keeps going, one generation at a time!

 

Content:

  • Sexual Reproduction
  • Asexual Reproduction

 

Content Standards: 

  1. Fertilization occurs when a male reproductive cell fuses with a female reproductive cell.

 

Learning Competency: 

  • explain that genetic information is passed on to offspring from both parents by the process of meiosis and fertilization;

Objectives:

At the end of this module the students must be able to;

  1. Describe the difference between sexual reproduction and asexual reproduction.
  2. Identify various modes of asexual reproduction 
  3. Recognize the role of reproduction maintaining life and species survival.

questions.question: Which type of reproduction involves only one parent and produces genetically identical offspring?
What is the term for the union of sperm and egg cells?
Which reproductive strategy involves eggs developing inside the mother and receiving nourishment from the yolk?
Which part of a flowering plant produces gametes for reproduction?
Which mode of asexual reproduction involves an organism dividing into two equal parts?

content_data.text:
Video Discussion of Comparing Ways Organism Reproduce

 

Tap to play:

REPRODUCTION OF ORGANISM

Reproduction refers to a process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring to maintain life from one generation to another.

There are two main types of reproduction:

  1. Sexual Reproduction
  2. Asexual Reproduction

Sexual reproduction 

 

Sexual Reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (male and female).Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes (sperm in males and eggs in females) that formed during meiosis.

 

 

 

These gametes (egg cells and sperm cells)unite in a process known as fertilization. This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, containing genes from both parents. You can observe this process in figure 3.1. 

 

 

 

Through this process the offspring have unique combinations of genes, explaining why offspring are genetically different from their parents.This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in

TYPES OF ANIMAL FERTILIZATION

 

External Fertilization

 

External fertilization happens in the external environment or outside of the body. This is commonly observed in many aquatic animals, as they simply release their eggs and sperm into the water that serves as a medium where the sperm swims to unite with an egg.

 

 

In figure 3.2, you can observe how external fertilization happens in aquatic animals like fish. The female fish releases several tiny eggs into the water, while the males also release sperm at the same time and in the same location. And through water movement, the sperm and egg combine, increasing the chances of fertilization to develop eggs and grow into new fish.

 

 

 

 

 

Internal fertilization

 

Internal fertilization is when the male deposits his sperm directly and fertilizes it inside of the female's body. 

 

During mating, the small, motile sperm are introduced into the female reproductive tract and swim up until they encounter a mature egg or oocyte in an oviduct where fertilization occurs. This type of fertilization provides more protection for the fertilized egg more especially as it develops into an embryo.

 

 

 

 

Animals that undergo this type of fertilization produce offspring in any of the following ways: oviparous, ovoviviparous, and viviparous.

 

Oviparous animals are those whose eggs are fertilized internally but  would complete their development outside the mother’s body. The egg would receive its nourishment through its yolk. This is found in some bony and cartilaginous fish (including clown fish), most reptiles, some amphibians, all birds, and a few mammals.

Ovoviviparous animals are those whose eggs are also fertilized internally and receive their nourishment through its yolk. But, the eggs will complete their development within the mother or inside the mother’s body. When they are then fully developed they are hatched and  released by the mother. 

 

Viviparous animals are those in which the eggs are developed internally and receive nourishment directly from the mother’s blood through the structure known placenta rather than from the yolk. This commonly occurs in most cartilaginous fish, some amphibians, a few reptiles, and almost all mammals including humans.

 

 

SEXUAL REPRODUCTION IN FLOWERING PLANTS 

 

In flowering plants, sexual reproduction occurs through flowers, which are the reproductive parts of angiospermous plants. Flowers contain structures that produce the gametes necessary for reproduction. 

 

In male flowers, the reproductive part is known as the stamen, which include two parts:the anther and filament. 

The anther is responsible for creating pollen grains that contain the gamete (sperm cells) and the filament is the one holding the anther in place to help the pollinators to  access the pollen. 

 

While in female flowers, the reproductive parts are known as the pistil, which includes stigma, style and ovary. Each part also has an individual role. The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

 

Once the sperm reaches the ovary, the fertilization occurs where the sperm combines with egg cells to  produce the zygote that develops into a seed.

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

 

Asexual Reproduction

 

Asexual Reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other, meaning they have the same traits. 

 

This type of reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle.

Modes of Asexual Reproduction

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant ( Figure 3.15 Artificial Vegetative Propagation).

read_aloud_data.content:
REPRODUCTION OF ORGANISM

Reproduction refers to a process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring to maintain life from one generation to another. Without this process, life on earth would stop and all species would disappear. But not all living organisms reproduce in the same way,some organisms reproduce on their own while others may need a partner. Reproduction in an organism may be classified into two types which are sexual and asexual reproduction.

Sexual reproduction 

 

Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (one male and one female). Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes—sperm in males and eggs in females. 

 

These gametes are formed during meiosis and come in the form of sperm cells (produced in the testes of males in the process known spermatogenesis) or egg cells (produced in the ovaries of females in the process known oogenesis).Under favorable conditions, the sperm and egg cells unite in a process known as fertilization.

 

This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, which contains genes from both parents. Hence, the offspring have unique combinations of genes, which explains why they are genetically different from their parents. This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments

Without this process, life on earth would stop and all species would disappear. Sexual reproduction 

 

Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (one male and one female). Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes—sperm in males and eggs in females. 

 

These gametes are formed during meiosis and come in the form of sperm cells (produced in the testes of males in the process known spermatogenesis) or egg cells (produced in the ovaries of females in the process known oogenesis).Under favorable conditions, the sperm and egg cells unite in a process known as fertilization.

 

This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, which contains genes from both parents. Hence, the offspring have unique combinations of genes, which explains why they are genetically different from their parents. This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments

TYPES OF ANIMAL FERTILIZATION

 

External Fertilization

 

External fertilization is characterized by the release of both sperm and egg into an external environment or outside of the body. This commonly occurs in many aquatic animals, as they simply release their eggs and sperm into the water. The water becomes the medium in which the sperm swims to unite with an egg.

 

The female releases several millions of tiny eggs into the water. The males, too, discharge almost at the same time in the same location. And through water movement, the sperm and egg combine. This way the chances of fertilization is greater.

Internal fertilization is when the male deposits his sperm directly and fertilizes it inside of the female's body. The small, motile sperm are introduced into the female reproductive tract during mating. The sperm cells swim up the reproductive tract until they encounter a mature egg or oocyte in an oviduct where fertilization occurs. This type of fertilization provides more protection for the fertilized egg more especially as it develops into an embryo.

 

Animals that undergo this type of fertilization produce offspring in any of the following ways: oviparous, ovoviviparous, and viviparous.

 

Oviparous animals are those whose eggs are fertilized internally but  would complete their development outside the mother’s body. The egg would receive its nourishment through its yolk. This is found in some bony and cartilaginous fish (including clown fish), most reptiles, some amphibians, all birds, and a few mammals.

 

Ovoviviparous animals are those whose eggs are also fertilized internally and receive their nourishment through its yolk. But, the eggs will complete their development within the mother or inside the mother’s body. When they are then fully developed they are hatched and  released by the mother. 

 

Viviparous animals are those in which the eggs are developed internally and receive nourishment directly from the mother’s blood through the structure known placenta rather than from the yolk. This commonly occurs in most cartilaginous fish, some amphibians, a few reptiles, and almost all mammals including humans.

SEXUAL REPRODUCTION IN FLOWERING PLANTS 

 

In flowering plants, sexual reproduction occurs through flowers, which are the reproductive parts of angiospermous plants. A flower is a specialized part of an angiospermous plant that occurs singly or in clusters, and possesses whorls of often colorful petals or sepals. It also  contains structures that produce the gametes necessary for reproduction. 

 

In male flowers, the reproductive part is known as the stamen, which include two parts: the anther and filament. The anther is responsible for creating pollen grains that contain the gamete (sperm cells) and the filament is the one holding the anther in place to help the pollinators to  access the pollen. 

 

While in female flowers, the reproductive parts are known as the pistil, which includes stigma, style and ovary. Each part also has an individual role. The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

 

Once the sperm reaches the ovary, the fertilization occurs where the sperm combines with egg cells to  produce the zygote that develops into a seed.

 

 

 

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

Asexual Reproduction

 

Asexual Reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the resulting offspring have the same genes and this is the reason why they have the same traits. 

 

In other words, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other. Asexual reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle.

Mode  of Asexual Reproduction in Plants

 

 

Types of Vegetative Propagation in Plants

 

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant.

Asexual Reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other, meaning they have the same traits. 

This type of reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle. 

 

Modes of Asexual Reproduction

Types of Vegetative Propagation in Plants

 

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant ( Figure 3.15 Artificial Vegetative Propagation).

REPRODUCTION OF ORGANISM

Reproduction refers to a process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring to maintain life from one generation to another. Without this process, life on earth would stop and all species would disappear. But not all living organisms reproduce in the same way,some organisms reproduce on their own while others may need a partner. Reproduction in an organism may be classified into two types which are sexual and asexual reproduction.

Sexual reproduction 

 

Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (one male and one female). Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes—sperm in males and eggs in females.

This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, which contains genes from both parents. This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments

content_data.text:
REPRODUCTION OF ORGANISM

Reproduction refers to a process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring to maintain life from one generation to another. Without this process, life on earth would stop and all species would disappear. But not all living organisms reproduce in the same way,some organisms reproduce on their own while others may need a partner. Reproduction in an organism may be classified into two types which are sexual and asexual reproduction.

Sexual reproduction 

 

Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (one male and one female). Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes—sperm in males and eggs in females. 

 

These gametes are formed during meiosis and come in the form of sperm cells (produced in the testes of males in the process known spermatogenesis) or egg cells (produced in the ovaries of females in the process known oogenesis).Under favorable conditions, the sperm and egg cells unite in a process known as fertilization.

 

This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, which contains genes from both parents. Hence, the offspring have unique combinations of genes, which explains why they are genetically different from their parents. This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments. 

                                                                        

TYPES OF ANIMAL FERTILIZATION

 

External Fertilization

 

External fertilization is characterized by the release of both sperm and egg into an external environment or outside of the body. This commonly occurs in many aquatic animals, as they simply release their eggs and sperm into the water. The water becomes the medium in which the sperm swims to unite with an egg.

 

The female releases several millions of tiny eggs into the water. The males, too, discharge almost at the same time in the same location. And through water movement, the sperm and egg combine. This way the chances of fertilization is greater.

Internal fertilization

 

Internal fertilization is when the male deposits his sperm directly and fertilizes it inside of the female's body. The small, motile sperm are introduced into the female reproductive tract during mating. The sperm cells swim up the reproductive tract until they encounter a mature egg or oocyte in an oviduct where fertilization occurs. This type of fertilization provides more protection for the fertilized egg more especially as it develops into an embryo.

 

Animals that undergo this type of fertilization produce offspring in any of the following ways: oviparous, ovoviviparous, and viviparous.

 

Oviparous animals are those whose eggs are fertilized internally but  would complete their development outside the mother’s body. The egg would receive its nourishment through its yolk. This is found in some bony and cartilaginous fish (including clown fish), most reptiles, some amphibians, all birds, and a few mammals.

 

Ovoviviparous animals are those whose eggs are also fertilized internally and receive their nourishment through its yolk. But, the eggs will complete their development within the mother or inside the mother’s body. When they are then fully developed they are hatched and  released by the mother. 

 

Viviparous animals are those in which the eggs are developed internally and receive nourishment directly from the mother’s blood through the structure known placenta rather than from the yolk. This commonly occurs in most cartilaginous fish, some amphibians, a few reptiles, and almost all mammals including humans.

SEXUAL REPRODUCTION IN FLOWERING PLANTS 

 

In flowering plants, sexual reproduction occurs through flowers, which are the reproductive parts of angiospermous plants. A flower is a specialized part of an angiospermous plant that occurs singly or in clusters, and possesses whorls of often colorful petals or sepals. It also  contains structures that produce the gametes necessary for reproduction. 

 

In male flowers, the reproductive part is known as the stamen, which include two parts: the anther and filament. The anther is responsible for creating pollen grains that contain the gamete (sperm cells) and the filament is the one holding the anther in place to help the pollinators to  access the pollen. 

 

While in female flowers, the reproductive parts are known as the pistil, which includes stigma, style and ovary. Each part also has an individual role. The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

 

Once the sperm reaches the ovary, the fertilization occurs where the sperm combines with egg cells to  produce the zygote that develops into a seed.

 

 

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

Asexual Reproduction

 

Asexual Reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the resulting offspring have the same genes and this is the reason why they have the same traits. 

 

In other words, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other. Asexual reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle. 

 

Modes of Asexual Reproduction

Mode of Asexual Reproduction in Plants

 

Types of Vegetative Propagation in Plants

 

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant ( Figure 3.15 Artificial Vegetative Propagation).

content_data.text:
REPRODUCTION OF ORGANISM

Imagine walking through a place full of life, where the plants are growing, animals giving birth, and seeds turning into new trees. Have you ever wondered how all these new lives begin?This happens through the process of reproduction.

Reproduction is a process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring to maintain life from one generation to another. Without this process, life on earth would stop and all species would disappear. 

But not all living organisms reproduce in the same way,some organisms reproduce on their own while others may need a partner. Reproduction in an organism may be classified into two types which are sexual and asexual reproduction.

Sexual reproduction 

 

Look at the people around you, particularly families of humans and other animals.Have you noticed that in a family, there is often a male (father) and a female (mother), but sometimes their children may not look exactly the same as them. Do you wonder why two parents are needed and how this happens? This happens because of sexual reproduction.  

 

Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (one male and one female). Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes—sperm in males and eggs in females. 

 

These gametes are formed during meiosis and come in the form of sperm cells (produced in the testes of males in the process known spermatogenesis) or egg cells (produced in the ovaries of females in the process known oogenesis).

Now, imagine what happens when the gametes (sperm cells and egg cells) meet and combine.Under favorable conditions, the sperm and egg cells unite in a process known as fertilization.

 

This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, which contains genes from both parents. Hence, the offspring have unique combinations of genes, which explains why they are genetically different from their parents. This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments. 

 

TYPES OF ANIMAL FERTILIZATION

 

Imagine and observe your surroundings, such as rivers,ponds, seas,forests and even your own community— you might notice different animals living in these places. But, have you wondered how fertilization occurs in these animals? Each animal carries out fertilization in a way that is suited to its environment.

There are two main types of fertilization in animals: external fertilization and internal fertilization. Each type happens differently depending on where and how the animals live.

External Fertilization

 

External fertilization is characterized by the release of both sperm and egg into an external environment or outside of the body. This is commonly observed in many aquatic animals, as they simply release their eggs and sperm into the water. The water becomes the medium in which the sperm swims to unite with an egg.

 

 

 

The female releases several millions of tiny eggs into the water. The males, too, discharge almost at the same time in the same location. And through water movement, the sperm and egg combine. This way the chances of fertilization is greater.

 

 

 

Internal Fertilization

 

Internal fertilization is when the male deposits his sperm directly and fertilizes it inside of the female's body. The small, motile sperm are introduced into the female reproductive tract during mating. The sperm cells swim up the reproductive tract until they encounter a mature egg or oocyte in an oviduct where fertilization occurs. 

 

This process is commonly seen in animals particularly mammals like humans, dogs, cats and also in other animals.  Fertilization happens when the sperm

cell meets the mature egg cell inside the female's body. The fertilized egg then develops and is safely protected inside as it grows.

However, not all animals that undergo internal fertilization produce offspring in the same way. Some animals lay eggs while others develop offspring inside the body and give birth to live young. Let’s discover and visualize the three types of internal fertilization oviparous, ovoviviparous, and viviparous.

 

Oviparous animals are those whose eggs are fertilized internally but  would complete their development outside the mother’s body. The egg would receive its nourishment through its yolk. This can be seen in some bony and cartilaginous fish (including clown fish), most reptiles, some amphibians, birds, and some mammals.

 

Ovoviviparous animals are those whose eggs are also fertilized internally and receive their nourishment through its yolk. But, the eggs will complete their development within the mother or inside the mother’s body. When they are then fully developed they are hatched and  released by the mother. 

 

Viviparous animals are those in which the eggs are developed internally and receive nourishment directly from the mother’s blood through the structure known placenta rather than from the yolk. This is commonly observed in most cartilaginous fish, some amphibians, a few reptiles, and almost all mammals including humans.

 

SEXUAL REPRODUCTION IN FLOWERING PLANTS 

 

If you have flowering plants in your school or house garden—like gumamela—take a moment to observe them closely. Look at their shape, color, and structure. Now, imagine how each part of the flower works to reproduce. 

In flowering plants, sexual reproduction occurs through flowers, which are the reproductive parts of angiospermous plants. A flower is a specialized part of an angiospermous plant that occurs singly or in clusters, and possesses whorls of often colorful petals or sepals. It also  contains structures that produce the gametes necessary for reproduction. 

 

In male flowers, the reproductive part is known as the stamen, which include two parts: the anther and filament. The anther is responsible for creating pollen grains that contain the gamete (sperm cells) and the filament is the one holding the anther in place to help the pollinators to  access the pollen. 

 

While in female flowers, the reproductive parts are known as the pistil, which includes stigma, style and ovary. Each part also has an individual role. The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves

as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

The sexual reproduction in flowering plants, for example, when a pollinator, like a bee, visits a flower to collect nectar. As it lands, it also picks up pollen grains that contain sperm cells from the anther of a male flower. When the bee visits a female flower, it transfers the pollen to the stigma. The pollen then travels down the style to reach the ovary. Once the sperm reaches the ovary, fertilization occurs—where the sperm combines with the egg cell to produce a zygote. This zygote develops into a seed, which can later grow into a new plant.

 

 

 

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

 

Asexual Reproduction

 

As you observe the surroundings, maybe you see plants growing from the ground, mushrooms on the trunk of a tree and molds forming on old bread. Have you ever wondered how these living things reproduce and grow even without a partner?That is because those living organisms reproduce through sexual reproduction. 

 

Sexual reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the resulting offspring have the same genes and this is the reason why they have the same traits. 

 

In other words, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other. Asexual reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle. 

 

Modes of Asexual Reproduction

 

There are different modes of asexual reproduction  and each one allows living organisms to reproduce in a way that suits its structure and environment. As you go through each type, try to picture how it happens and imagine how each organism grows and survives.

Types of Vegetative Propagation in Plants

 

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant ( Figure 3.15 Artificial Vegetative Propagation).

 

 

.

While in female flowers, the reproductive parts are known as the pistil, which includes stigma, style and ovary. Each part also has an individual role. The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

 

Once the sperm reaches the ovary, the fertilization occurs where the sperm combines with egg cells to  produce the zygote that develops into a seed.

 

 

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

Asexual Reproduction

 

Asexual Reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the resulting offspring have the same genes and this is the reason why they have the same traits. 

 

In other words, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other. Asexual reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle. 

 

Modes of Asexual Reproduction

Mode  of Asexual Reproduction in Plants

 

 

Types of Vegetative Propagation in Plants

 

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant.

This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments. 

                                                                        

TYPES OF ANIMAL FERTILIZATION

 

External Fertilization

 

External fertilization is characterized by the release of both sperm and egg into an external environment or outside of the body. This commonly occurs in many aquatic animals, as they simply release their eggs and sperm into the water. The water becomes the medium in which the sperm swims to unite with an egg.

 

The female releases several millions of tiny eggs into the water. The males, too, discharge almost at the same time in the same location. And through water movement, the sperm and egg combine. This way the chances of fertilization is greater.

Internal fertilization

 

Internal fertilization is when the male deposits his sperm directly and fertilizes it inside of the female's body. The small, motile sperm are introduced into the female reproductive tract during mating. The sperm cells swim up the reproductive tract until they encounter a mature egg or oocyte in an oviduct where fertilization occurs. This type of fertilization provides more protection for the fertilized egg more especially as it develops into an embryo.

 

Animals that undergo this type of fertilization produce offspring in any of the following ways: oviparous, ovoviviparous, and viviparous.

 

Oviparous animals are those whose eggs are fertilized internally but  would complete their development outside the mother’s body. The egg would receive its nourishment through its yolk. This is found in some bony and cartilaginous fish (including clown fish), most reptiles, some amphibians, all birds, and a few mammals.

 

Ovoviviparous animals are those whose eggs are also fertilized internally and receive their nourishment through its yolk. But, the eggs will complete their development within the mother or inside the mother’s body. When they are then fully developed they are hatched and  released by the mother. 

 

Viviparous animals are those in which the eggs are developed internally and receive nourishment directly from the mother’s blood through the structure known placenta rather than from the yolk. This commonly occurs in most cartilaginous fish, some amphibians, a few reptiles, and almost all mammals including humans.

In flowering plants, sexual reproduction occurs through flowers, which are the reproductive parts of angiospermous plants. A flower is a specialized part of an angiospermous plant that occurs singly or in clusters, and possesses whorls of often colorful petals or sepals. It also  contains structures that produce the gametes necessary for reproduction.

The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

 

Once the sperm reaches the ovary, the fertilization occurs where the sperm combines with egg cells to  produce the zygote that develops into a seed.

 

 

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

In other words, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other. Asexual reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle.

read_aloud_data.content:
REPRODUCTION OF ORGANISM

Imagine walking through a place full of life, where the plants are growing, animals giving birth, and seeds turning into new trees. Have you ever wondered how all these new lives begin?This happens through the process of reproduction.

Reproduction is a process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring to maintain life from one generation to another. Without this process, life on earth would stop and all species would disappear. 

But not all living organisms reproduce in the same way,some organisms reproduce on their own while others may need a partner. Reproduction in an organism may be classified into two types which are sexual and asexual reproduction.

 

Sexual reproduction 

 

Look at the people around you, particularly families of humans and other animals.Have you noticed that in a family, there is often a male (father) and a female (mother), but sometimes their children may not look exactly the same as them. Do you wonder why two parents are needed and how this happens? This happens because of sexual reproduction.  

 

Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (one male and one female). Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes—sperm in males and eggs in females. 

 

These gametes are formed during meiosis and come in the form of sperm cells (produced in the testes of males in the process known spermatogenesis) or egg cells (produced in the ovaries of females in the process known oogenesis). 

 

Now, imagine what happens when the gametes (sperm cells and egg cells) meet and combine.Under favorable conditions, the sperm and egg cells unite in a process known as fertilization.

 

This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, which contains genes from both parents. Hence, the offspring have unique combinations of genes, which explains why they are genetically different from their parents. This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments.

TYPES OF ANIMAL FERTILIZATION

 

Imagine and observe your surroundings, such as rivers,ponds, seas,forests and even your own community— you might notice different animals living in these places. But, have you wondered how fertilization occurs in these animals? Each animal carries out fertilization in a way that is suited to its environment.

There are two main types of fertilization in animals: external fertilization and internal fertilization. Each type happens differently depending on where and how the animals live.

External Fertilization

 

External fertilization is characterized by the release of both sperm and egg into an external environment or outside of the body. This is commonly observed in many aquatic animals, as they simply release their eggs and sperm into the water. The water becomes the medium in which the sperm swims to unite with an egg.

 

 

 

The female releases several millions of tiny eggs into the water. The males, too, discharge almost at the same time in the same location. And through water movement, the sperm and egg combine. This way the chances of fertilization is greater.

 

 

 

Internal Fertilization

 

Internal fertilization is when the male deposits his sperm directly and fertilizes it inside of the female's body. The small, motile sperm are introduced into the female reproductive tract during mating. The sperm cells swim up the reproductive tract until they encounter a mature egg or oocyte in an oviduct where fertilization occurs. 

 

This process is commonly seen in animals particularly mammals like humans, dogs, cats and also in other animals.  Fertilization happens when the sperm cell meets the mature egg cell inside the female's body. The fertilized egg then develops and is safely protected inside as it grows.

 

However, not all animals that undergo internal fertilization produce offspring in the same way. Some animals lay eggs while others develop offspring inside the body and give birth to live young. Let’s discover and visualize the three types of internal fertilization oviparous, ovoviviparous, and viviparous.

 

Oviparous animals are those whose eggs are fertilized internally but  would complete their development outside the mother’s body. The egg would receive its nourishment through its yolk. This can be seen in some bony and cartilaginous fish (including clown fish), most reptiles, some amphibians, birds, and some mammals.

 

Ovoviviparous animals are those whose eggs are also fertilized internally and receive their nourishment through its yolk. But, the eggs will complete their development within the mother or inside the mother’s body. When they are then fully developed they are hatched and  released by the mother. 

 

Viviparous animals are those in which the eggs are developed internally and receive nourishment directly from the mother’s blood through the structure known placenta rather than from the yolk. This is commonly observed in most cartilaginous fish, some amphibians, a few reptiles, and almost all mammals including humans.

SEXUAL REPRODUCTION IN FLOWERING PLANTS 

 

If you have flowering plants in your school or house garden—like gumamela—take a moment to observe them closely. Look at their shape, color, and structure. Now, imagine how each part of the flower works to reproduce. 

In flowering plants, sexual reproduction occurs through flowers, which are the reproductive parts of angiospermous plants. A flower is a specialized part of an angiospermous plant that occurs singly or in clusters, and possesses whorls of often colorful petals or sepals. It also  contains structures that produce the gametes necessary for reproduction. 

 

In male flowers, the reproductive part is known as the stamen, which include two parts: the anther and filament. The anther is responsible for creating pollen grains that contain the gamete (sperm cells) and the filament is the one holding the anther in place to help the pollinators to  access the pollen. 

 

While in female flowers, the reproductive parts are known as the pistil, which includes stigma, style and ovary. Each part also has an individual role. The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

 

The sexual reproduction in flowering plants, for example, when a pollinator, like a bee, visits a flower to collect nectar. As it lands, it also picks up pollen grains that contain sperm cells from the anther of a male flower. When the bee visits a female flower, it transfers the pollen to the stigma. The pollen then travels down the style to reach the ovary. Once the sperm reaches the ovary, fertilization occurs—where the sperm combines with the egg cell to produce a zygote. This zygote develops into a seed, which can later grow into a new plant.

 

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

Asexual Reproduction

 

As you observe the surroundings, maybe you see plants growing from the ground, mushrooms on the trunk of a tree and molds forming on old bread. Have you ever wondered how these living things reproduce and grow even without a partner?That is because those living organisms reproduce through sexual reproduction. 

 

Sexual reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the resulting offspring have the same genes and this is the reason why they have the same traits. 

 

In other words, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other. Asexual reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle. 

 

 

Modes of Asexual Reproduction

 

There are different modes of asexual reproduction  and each one allows living organisms to reproduce in a way that suits its structure and environment. As you go through each type, try to picture how it happens and imagine how each organism grows and survives.

Types of Vegetative Propagation in Plants

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant( Figure 3.15 Artificial Vegetative Propagation).

read_aloud_data.content:
REPRODUCTION OF ORGANISM

Reproduction refers to a process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring to maintain life from one generation to another. Without this process, life on earth would stop and all species would disappear. But not all living organisms reproduce in the same way,some organisms reproduce on their own while others may need a partner. Reproduction in an organism may be classified into two types which are sexual and asexual reproduction.

Sexual reproduction 

 

Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves two parents (one male and one female). Each parent produces reproductive cells called gametes—sperm in males and eggs in females. 

 

These gametes are formed during meiosis and come in the form of sperm cells (produced in the testes of males in the process known spermatogenesis) or egg cells (produced in the ovaries of females in the process known oogenesis).Under favorable conditions, the sperm and egg cells unite in a process known as fertilization.

 

This union forms a fertilized egg  or known as zygote, which contains genes from both parents. Hence, the offspring have unique combinations of genes, which explains why they are genetically different from their parents. This genetic variety helps organisms to survive and adapt quickly in changing environments

TYPES OF ANIMAL FERTILIZATION

 

External Fertilization

 

External fertilization is characterized by the release of both sperm and egg into an external environment or outside of the body. This commonly occurs in many aquatic animals, as they simply release their eggs and sperm into the water. The water becomes the medium in which the sperm swims to unite with an egg.

 

The female releases several millions of tiny eggs into the water. The males, too, discharge almost at the same time in the same location. And through water movement, the sperm and egg combine. This way the chances of fertilization is greater.

 

 

 

Internal fertilization

 

Internal fertilization is when the male deposits his sperm directly and fertilizes it inside of the female's body. The small, motile sperm are introduced into the female reproductive tract during mating. The sperm cells swim up the reproductive tract until they encounter a mature egg or oocyte in an oviduct where fertilization occurs. This type of fertilization provides more protection for the fertilized egg more especially as it develops into an embryo.

 

Animals that undergo this type of fertilization produce offspring in any of the following ways: oviparous, ovoviviparous, and viviparous.

 

Oviparous animals are those whose eggs are fertilized internally but  would complete their development outside the mother’s body. The egg would receive its nourishment through its yolk. This is found in some bony and cartilaginous fish (including clown fish), most reptiles, some amphibians, all birds, and a few mammals.

 

Ovoviviparous animals are those whose eggs are also fertilized internally and receive their nourishment through its yolk. But, the eggs will complete their development within the mother or inside the mother’s body. When they are then fully developed they are hatched and  released by the mother. 

 

Viviparous animals are those in which the eggs are developed internally and receive nourishment directly from the mother’s blood through the structure known placenta rather than from the yolk. This commonly occurs in most cartilaginous fish, some amphibians, a few reptiles, and almost all mammals including humans.

SEXUAL REPRODUCTION IN FLOWERING PLANTS 

 

In flowering plants, sexual reproduction occurs through flowers, which are the reproductive parts of angiospermous plants. A flower is a specialized part of an angiospermous plant that occurs singly or in clusters, and possesses whorls of often colorful petals or sepals. It also  contains structures that produce the gametes necessary for reproduction. 

 

In male flowers, the reproductive part is known as the stamen, which include two parts: the anther and filament. The anther is responsible for creating pollen grains that contain the gamete (sperm cells) and the filament is the one holding the anther in place to help the pollinators to  access the pollen. 

 

While in female flowers, the reproductive parts are known as the pistil, which includes stigma, style and ovary. Each part also has an individual role. The stigma is the one that receives the pollen grains, while the style connects the stigma to the ovary and serves as the pathways for the sperm cells to travel. Then, the ovary contains the ovules that have egg cells. 

 

Once the sperm reaches the ovary, the fertilization occurs where the sperm combines with egg cells to  produce the zygote that develops into a seed.

 

 

 

Moreover, flowering plants may reproduce sexually because of their structure. However, not all plants and animals need two parents to reproduce.Many kinds of plants and lower forms of animals produce new individuals by asexual reproduction.

Asexual Reproduction

 

As you observe the surroundings, maybe you see plants growing from the ground, mushrooms on the trunk of a tree and molds forming on old bread. Have you ever wondered how these living things reproduce and grow even without a partner?That is because those living organisms reproduce through sexual reproduction. 

 

Sexual reproduction is the creation of a new organism from a single parent without a combination of gametes. Therefore, the parent and the resulting offspring have the same genes and this is the reason why they have the same traits. 

 

In other words, the parent and the offspring are identical to each other. Asexual reproduction requires less energy since no mating is needed but can produce many offspring at one reproductive cycle. 

 

Modes of Asexual Reproduction

 

There are different modes of asexual reproduction  and each one allows living organisms to reproduce in a way that suits its structure and environment. As you go through each type, try to picture how it happens and imagine how each organism grows and survives.

Types of Vegetative Propagation in Plants

 

 

These various types of vegetative propagation are natural as they occur without human help. However, vegetative propagation can happen artificially through human intervention. People help new plants to grow using several techniques like stem cutting. For example, in gumamela, when a person cuts the stem of gumamela and plants it in soil or a flowerplot, it will develop roots and eventually grow into a new plant ( Figure 3.15 Artificial Vegetative Propagation).

statements.statement: Sexual Reproduction involves only single parents to reproduce.
Internal Fertilization occurs inside the female's body.
Fragmentation is a mode of sexual reproduction where an organism replaces or repairs a lost damaged part of the body.
Budding is where a new organism or offspring and eventually separate to become a new individual.
Vegetative propagation is a type of sexual reproduction in plants, where a new plant can develop from the root, stem or leaf of an already existing plant.

activity_data.detailed_instructions:
Instructions:

  1. Choose any type or mode of reproduction
  • For sexual reproduction: Flowering plant, Human, Frog
  • For asexual reproduction Budding, Binary Fission, Fragmentation, etc.
  1. Using clay or paper cutouts, create a simple model that shows how your chosen mode or type of reproduction occurs in an organism.
  2. Label your model using a toothpick or stick. Write the name of the organism and the process you are showing.
  3. Answer the following guide questions, on your paper.

questions.question: What is the process in which living organisms form a new life or offspring?

options: C. Plants will stop making food
questions.question: What will happen to life on Earth if reproduction does not occur?
Which type of reproduction involves two parents?
Which type of reproduction needs only one parent?
What are the special cells provided by each parent in sexual reproduction?
When an egg cell and sperm cell combine during fertilization, what is formed?

options: A. A dog giving birth to puppies
B. A hydra forming a bud
C. A man and woman having a child
questions.question: Which of the following is an example of asexual reproduction?
questions.correct_answer: B. A hydra forming a bud

questions.question: Which is an advantage of sexual reproduction?

options: B. Takes a long time to complete
C. Produces little or no variation
D. Produces only a few offspring
questions.question: Which is a disadvantage of asexual reproduction?
questions.correct_answer: C. Produces little or no variation

options: A. It allows life to continue from one generation to the next
B. It helps organisms breathe better
C. It makes plants grow taller
D. It gives energy for movement
questions.question: Why is reproduction important in the survival of species?
questions.correct_answer: A. It allows life to continue from one generation to the next
